transcript.content: The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Hello, welcome to the 8th in this series of twelve podcasts, the Ricky Gervais show with the Guardian. I'm Ricky Gervais. Hello. With me, Stephen Merchant.
Hello.
Er, and Karl Pilkington.
Alright
So, thank you again for all your emails. We're getting thousands. We're up to about a quarter of a million hits a week now. People listening to this show.
Blimey.
A quarter of a million people bothering to go and listen to show.
Nothing else in their lives, nothing better to do.
All around the world.

It's unbelievable though, North America, Asia, South America, all over Europe. And thanks to everyone in England as well where we do it from, in a little room in London. Keep going to Ricky Gervais.com and registering because so when we finish these twelve, we can email you when we come back and start again. We're going to need a little bit of time off to record the second series of extras.
Well, I tell you more than that, Rick, you're gonna need some time off just to have a little breather because I know how hard you work.
And you, mate,
Well thanks, mate, but I mean you blinking work hard.
But Karl's been on holiday again, hasn't he?
Oh yeah, that's right, yeah. Cause Karl, you- you don't do anything...
And you have weekends off. You take at least five or six weeks holiday a year even though you haven't got a job now, you're meant to be doing this and yet you still go on holiday-
So your whole life's a holiday basically
Yeah. Why do you need a holiday to you, you...potter around? Your big day last week was going to the cobblers. So why did you need a break so much this week?
It's just that, you know, it's good for your brain and that innit, it, it opens it up a bit.
You are not evidence for that.
Where did you go?
Gran Canaria.
For a week?
Yeah.
Just sitting around?

Erm, well, there isn't much else to do at Gran Canaria. I mean, I don't want to go slagging a place off because every time I seem to talk about somewhere, I get into trouble for it - but it's just like a big rock.
Yeah
It's just volcanic innit.
And you must have looked like a little barnacle on that.
Have you been there before?
Erm, been, been near it before to another rock, which was just, it was the same sort of thing-
But what, you've had your fingers burned, why did you go back?
Because you think, well, they can't have loads of these islands that are the same, like just a big rock with hotels on. They can't get away with it, so you think well the next one-
Well they obviously are getting away with it. Why? Why do you keep going to these places that are rocks. Why don't you investigate first? Ask your travel agent, is this a giant rock?

Because, because that's what you do innit? You go and find out yourself. I mean, when, when Armstrong went to the moon, what was he expecting up there? That's a fact. That it's a big rock. And he still went all that way.
I don't know what that point was.
No, so what I'm saying is, though, sometimes it, it-

Tell us about, the- tell us about the moon landing as you started it. What do you know about that? You know, because, I mean, so far you've given us a lot of insight into, into the, the moon landing. So there was Armstrong-
There was, there was Armstrong and that.
Yeah.
There was erm, fella called Buzz.
Yeah.
And another bloke.
Yeah. Poor bastard
Yeah. Never remembered.
Yeah. Go on.

And er... they went up there, got out. Two of them did. One of them didn't bother. The one whose name. Don't know who he was. Didn't even get out, stretch his legs. Right. Went all that way. They had a potter about, had a wander, came back again.
Yeah.
So that's all you need to know in it.
Yeah.
And in your opinion: pointless?
Um, to me, yeah. But to them, I'm sure they had a good time. And that's what I'm saying. Sometimes you just take the risk, don't you? Go and visit a place, make up your own mind.
And so you, what do you make of this place? You enjoy it - Grand Canaria? It was just a big rock, but did you..?
I bet the moon was better. (Ricky laughs)
Really?
What did you do?

It was just, uh, you know, it's one of them. It's big hotel, which is, that's where I made a mistake. It was one of those, like, big, massive places where there's loads of people and, you know, you go for your dinner.
That describes a hotel.
Yeah. Sounds like one to me!
No, no.
You've nailed that.
I've been to a few. That sounds like it. (Ricky laughs)

No, do you know what I mean, though? There's the sort, there's the nice small ones where it's just enough people, but this is, like, mental. And, and it was all. It was, it was full of old people, really.
Ugh
I mean, that's probably why it's called Gran Canaria, right? Because it's just old people-
Grannies everywhere?
Yeah, right. But what I thought I'd start doing is, uh, start a diary.
Okay. Why?
Just 'cos I sort of had a bit of time on my hands and that just thought, write it down. Write, write stuff down.
And do you hope that this one day will become one of the great literary documents - like Samuel Pepys diary?
Um, I haven't heard of that. Is it any good?
(Ricky laughs)
You've never heard of Samuel Pepys diary?
No. The, the-
The most famous diary, er, other than probably Anne Frank's.
I've heard of Anne Frank's and that. And I thought if she's sat in a, you know, a loft, knocking stuff up, not much going on in her life at that point yet-
Sure.
Yet she was still writing it down.
Yeah, whereas you've been to Gran Canaria.
I thought, I'm on holiday - I thought, so there is stuff going on that I can chat about. Start a diary.
Sure.
You started a diary?
Yeah.
And what you gonna do, you, did you, did you keep it up, every day?
Yeah. Just er-
Oh can I read it? Please?
Well, a diary is meant to be sort of-
Please can I read some out on this podcast? I- Karl-
Some of it, though, is only relevant to me, it's sort of-
Oh, this is. Please give me it. Oh, my God.
I mean, this isn't, I haven't just-
Look how big it is! (Ricky and Steve laugh)
It's one of those desk diaries.

Oh my God! It's huge. It's about a foot long and it's ma-. Oh, that is amazing. Imagine if Anne Frank's had been like that, as she got it out "doof", right. Everyone would have heard it clank down on the desk.
Yeah, but me writing's quite big, innit?
Oh, look, give us that.
Do you know about joined up writing? Have you heard about that?
No point, sometimes you can't read it, can you? So it's best to-
Right, okay.
Look at, look at ancient times...

Oh, oh look, oh my God. It starts on the first day. This is, this is wonderful. Going on holiday to Grand Canaria today. Woke up to the news that Tony Banks had died. There was a piece of on the news about how everyone was shocked. Got me thinking about an invention that would be good, right? A watch that counted down your life. If it says you've got three days left, go to the doctors- (Ricky and Steve laugh) Told Suzanne about invention. She said she wouldn't buy a one, but she said that about the iPod.

How er... And how would this device work, this watch? I mean, how would you er, how would you know when you were about to die? Have you- is that a consideration - again not for you to worry about, presumably the boffins must-
No, all I was thinking is that Tony Banks fella, you know, he died and everyone was shocked about it. But if you had like a little watch on-

But how did it, but- you can't just say, wouldn't it be good? How would this work? Yeah, I imagine you in the patent office going, got an idea. They go, oh, certainly er Mister Pilkington, what's your idea? Watch that counted down your life. Oh, how does that work?
Just pop it on your wrist.
No, no. What do you mean- just pop it on your wrist? How does it work? Just pop it on your wrist. Brilliant. You're an idiot.

Well, it's interesting that he goes on. The flight to Grand Canary was a bit bumpy. I thought about the clock that counts down your life again and I wondered if it would know if you were gonna die in a disaster. (Ricky laughs)
Now, he's querying his own, his own design-
He's wondering if he would know. He's invented this and (laughs)
A fella on the plane was reading 'Koi mag'. It was a fishing magazine. I glanced over and noticed he was reading the pond of the month article.
(Ricky laughs)

Don't think they could make it into a weekly magazine. Well, to be fair to you I, because I remember seeing a guy on the train once reading 'Carp Monthly', a magazine dedicated entirely to carp, and it had carp of the month. And I just thought, you know, once you're like, three months in, the editor must be stressing. Have we got any more carpet? We got a carp that's actually done anything.
I reckon if they used the same one twice, there wouldn't be many complaints.
No one would be noticing.
No - that's the carp they used two years ago.

There was a really fat bloke on the plane. He was playing on his PSP. While I waited to go to the toilet, I looked at what game he was playing. It was darts. He's that fat and lazy he can't even face playing a more active game on a games console.
(Ricky laughs)

Me and Suzanne got off the coach along with a couple of old people. One of them was in a wheelchair. I don't think it was wise of them to come to a volcanic island with a wheelchair. Everywhere is pretty rough paving and slopey. Guess I'll keep an eye on it as the weeks go on. Day two in Gran Canaria.
Brilliant. We're only at day two.
The hotel is a bit odd. I've never seen as many cross-eyed people in one location.
(Ricky laughs)
That's enough, innit?
That's amazing.
Well, if you both let me read on a bit more.
Right, well this is amazing.
Well, come back to it later, though
This is a brilliant diary. This might be the best diary ever written. Oh.
Whilst sat listening to 'The Kinks' on my iPod, I wondered if everybody thinks in their accent. I know I do. What's this? What are you talking about?
Just. Just that, er you know, when I, when I've been sat there, lying on the lounger, right, and I was thinking about stuff.
How do you know you think in your accent? Tell me a typical thought.
Because, because what I mean is say, say if I was like, if I saw something, right? Do you know how I say, like, oh, that's a bit weird, innit?
No but-
That was being said-

I don't have to, but in, when you think, I don't think the sentence as like I'm saying it. It's just a thought. The thought appears. It's conceptual and it's already there. It's not like, um, I go, Rick. What? Just, uh, looking at a fellow over there, were you? Yeah, I was. Yeah. Um, I was thinking it looks a bit weird. Oh, so was I. I don't, I don't think out whole sentences.
Whereas you have, Karl, Karl, Karl, stop listening to 'The Kinks' for a minute. Look over there. More- more cross-eyed people.
No, well that's, yeah that's-
Is that how your mind works?
In a way, yeah.
Brilliant.
That explains a lot.
That's great, he has to think out whole sentences

Cause I thought "that's weird, innit?" Right? I didn't think "that's weird, isn't it?" And I thought, I actually think in my accent. And then I thought, does Stephen Hawking? Does he? When he's doing his maths and that.  Is he, I don't know where he's from, so I don't know what his accent would be like.
I think he's from Kent or Cambridge or Oxford.
Right, so
So you think he might think in his,
In his, in that voice box thing.
Computerized voice.
Just wondered.

Had lunch inside today due to shite weather. Sat next to an old fella. Old men's ears and noses carry on growing as they get older. Suzanne noticed his fingers were fat too. Maybe they continued to grow. Suzanne didn't laugh when I said her arse had the same problem.
*Laughing* Oh God

Day three, cloudy start to the day. Had pie and chips in a cafe. Had a bit of an argument with Suzanne cause I thought it was daft that we were paying for food when we were on an all inclusive holiday. Changed my mind when I saw that they sold pie, though. The cafe was called tattoos. The fellow who owned it didn't have any tattoos, but we never saw his wife.
*Laughing* Oh, brilliant.
Had a drink in a bar. Everyone sat and watched one of the local cats lick its bollocks.
*Laughing* It's the greatest holiday in the world!  That's the entertainment in that town!
Went back to the hotel and had a sleep before tea. I love the fact you're like, you're moaning about old people, but you're just as bad.
He's done nothing so far.
He's done nothing and he's gone for a kip.
Oh, God, Karl.
Woke up to news about ducks being badly treated. There was a really ugly one with bent legs.
*Laughing* I'm gonna die. I'm gonna die. Why does he write this down. Oh, God. Oh.

There is a fat bloke from Bolton who is in the pool as I write this. He's got a big tattoo on his back, but I can't work out what it is. Dot, dot, dot. He just got out of the pool and burped. You just felt like you had to keep us abreast of that?
Everything's in the diary. I just seen it, it'll get to the point where you're going. "Breathed in."
Yeah,
"Breathed out again."

There was a big fat fella in the sea who kept his t shirt on. If you're big and fat, is there more chance of you getting burnt because there's more of you on show? I asked Suzanne and she said she didn't know in that sort of not listening kind of way. I wanted to hang about to see if the fat bloke was going to get in the kayak, but Suzanne said we had a head back. Just sat there wait in to see if he's gonna capsize. We go home today, so we got up early to get the last bit of cloud.

No, it's just that it wasn't. It's not that sunny all the time. I mean, I was sat in, in weather that if it was like that here, there's no way I'd be sat in the garden. But because you're on holiday, it's like, well, we got to sit in it. Put your coat on.
So are you gonna continue to write this diary? Every single da-
It's amazing! Keep this diary up. It's amazing.
No, I will keep it up because what I find as well is, I think earlier on before I went away, I think I did learn something. And because I wrote it down, I remembered it a bit umm, better. So.
What was that?
I just was thinking then I forgot it now. But...
Steve and Ricky laugh.
But I remembered looking back at it and not having to read it all because I remembered the end of it before I read it, if you know what I mean.
I have no idea what you're talking about.

Well, if you've enjoyed the diary of Karl Pilkington, more next week I hope—another week's worth. That's amazing. I'm going to try and get that published. We put the odd page up on the web, go to RickyGervais.com. Don't forget to register there as well so we can email you and let you know uhh—what's happening. Brilliant.
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Hey, fool! Don't give me no back chat, sucker. I ain't here to mess with you. I ain't getting in no plane. I'm here to tell you all about Friday night comedy on Channel Four.

Hmm. There's three great new comedies: New Green Wing. Yeah, fool! That's nearly ready. My name is Earl and The I.T. crowd. They're great new comedy from the creator of Father Ted, sucker! Friday night comedy this Friday on Channel Four fool! Switch it on or I'll be round your house. You stay up all night shivering, 'cause you be so mad scared!... Fool!
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Rick, who hosts this podcast?
The guys at positive Internet, why?
Now, I know you're a big fan of those guys.
Yeah, because they're brilliant.

Well, they are. And I tell you they're working overtime because we've had an email from Jake, who's the director at Positive Internet, and apparently he's been in touch with the editor of the Guinness World Records book.
All right.

And he's hoping to see if we can get this podcast, in the Guinness World Record breaking section or the podcast world record breaking section or whatever they call it. I don't know exactly what record we have broken. I assume it's just sheer number of listeners, is it? Or...?
Yeah, it's the number one podcast, and it's the biggest downloaded show ever at the moment. I think that's because people have only had podcasts for a couple of years.
Yea so I don't know. I mean, I don't know when the next issue comes out. I guess it's sort of December time.
I used to get the Guinness book records every year. I love it.

I've never understood why it was such a big seller. I mean, presumably, who's excited to find out whether, you know, I don't know. A man that can balance three egg cups on his head has beaten the record.
Well, they're real records as well, obviously. I used to go straight for that. I really loved the sort of animals, fastest, strongest, all that sort of thing. Biggest.
But aren't they the same every year?

Well, no, they do change, and obviously there's new entries to keep it exciting. But what annoys me is that it looks like anyone can get in if you're willing to do something that no one else will bother with.
Yeah.
They did one on big Brother where it was the umm... stacking sugar cubes, and I was thinking well, no one's gonna bother beating that.
No.

There's people that walk along with a milk butter on their head. And no one's going "Aw I'm A bit jealous of bill", "Why?", "He's broken the record.", "What, for walking along with a milk bottle on his head?", "Yeah. I'm gonna go into training tomorrow.".
They're ridiculous.
Yeah, yeah.

You know, but I do like the, you know, the real ones. There was one in there I got on a couple of years ago, and it was about disasters. And there was one where there was some big ornamental incense burners at this thing in, I think, Thailand or Korea or somewhere, and they fell over and they killed seven of the congregation. And the headline was, biggest joss stick disaster. Now, again, there's no one trying to beat that. There's no one going, we need eight. We need eight people. We're going for it tonight. What do I have to do? You have to stand quite near those big joss sticks. Okay.
And what record am I breaking again?

Um, we'll tell you after. Also, I think a lot of people waste their energy on this because there's one guy in there that can do the hundred meters in 11 seconds running backwards. And I want to say to him, turn round, because I think you'd be fast forwards, you know, if you'd have only from the age of ten, sort of, you might be, you know, one of the fastest runners in the world.
Because you're never going to be considered one of the great athletes for doing it backwards.
No one knows about him. That's not going to ever be an Olympic sport, running backwards or. Well, and now the hundred meters. Oh, one of them is putting a milk bottle on his head.

Yeah, this is one to watch. There was a guy in there. I've always been fascinated by the guy. He had the world's longest fingernails, and they were truly extraordinary. And they, and they went out and they started to curl round, obviously, and in the end, they almost looked like sort of a, you know, there's a big spiral of gnarled old fingernail. But I just thought it just seemed like such a terrible affliction, really, to be walking around, you know, with, with these giant fingernails. So much you can't do. Just missing out on, you know. "Jeff, you coming bowling?" "I can't," you know, just so many different things that you've missed out on. I've never quite understood who's willing to, to have this eat into their life. You know, it's going to take over their whole life just so they can have their photo in this book. It seems a very bizarre impulse. Karl, have you ever been tempted by any world record attempts? Do you find them fascinating or futile?
Um, I mean, you don't get, you don't get paid or anything, do you?
No, they do it for the pride.

But say, like the fellow who can run with a milk bottle, could he could he get a milk round? Do you know what I mean? I can understand that if you can use the skill, but like you say, if it's, if it's getting in the way your life and that, then what's the point?

There was a kid at school who said, "I'm in the Guinness Book of Records." I went, "Oh, yeah, yeah." He said, "No, I am. I am. I am." And he brought it in and it, now, I don't know if this is a valid claim. He claimed to have been in the audience for what, in this particular edition was labeled, you know, the largest audience ever for a sporting event, some giant Super Bowl game in America and he claimed to have been in the audience. Now, does that. Do you think he deserves to say he's in the Guinness Book of Records?
Well, sort of. I think that's a lot. As it was the largest audience ever. I think a lot of people can claim that one. I mean-

If he wanted to get a name check on doing that, he would have been best saying, I was sat in the audience in a bath of beans, because then that would add to it and you get a little, you know, they have you in the picture, wouldn't they? So-
He's missed out there.
Yeah.
The Ricky Gervais Show on Guardian Unlimited.

Harry from Canterbury wants to know whether any of us have ever had any cruel nicknames. He claims that he's quite tall and rather hirsute, and he says he's often called Lurch or Wolfy. He's always thought that Carl looks a bit like Mister Potato head.

Yeah. No, there's no potato that round, but I suppose you could fashion a potato to be that round. Maybe we could. If anyone can carve a potato into the roundest head ever, pop a couple of eyes on it.
Make it look as much like Carl as possible.
Exactly.
But, yeah. Did any nicknames. Did you ever have a nickname, Rick?
No, mom's boring. I didn't have any. Was just around the name, like Jerv or something like that. No, I didn't have nicknames.
I always wanted a nickname. I just thought it was quite cool for some reason, particularly because gangsters always seem to have nicknames. Lefty fingers.
Yeah.
Yeah. Scarface.
Yeah.
And so I decided that. I thought, because no one was giving me a nickname at school, it was kind of annoying, or certainly not to my face.
Yeah.
That I decided to just come up with one. And so I went. I remember I was at lunch once and I just said to my mate.
Phil, how old were you?
Brilliant.
I just said to him, phil, don't know if you know, mate, but people aren't calling me Steve anymore.
Everyone's.
Everyone's calling me Spud now. Now. I don't know why I thought Spud. It's weird. We should talk about. I don't know why I thought Spud was a. Was a cool nickname. I just.
It's a grown up name, though, in it.

And it's also because I think it sounded like it was probably either something that you'd find in one of those kids books, like the Famous five, or, like, the Bash street kids. That'd be spud. And I always imagine with Spud, he's not the leader of the gang, but he's a reliable member, I think is.
The biggest lorry driver in one particular sort of car park.
Yeah.
Come, Spud.
Yeah.
And he gets out, all right, boys. And he's big and massive. And Spud can eat two breakfasts.
Exactly. Yeah. But I just. In my mind, it was. Yeah. That I would be one day part of a gang. And it's. I'm Pinky. This is Joe. Joe and the tall guy, Spud.
And, you know, really quite.
And he just went, oh, yeah, right. And no one started. I was hoping he'd go, you know, everyone's calling Steve Spud.
Yeah.
But of course.
Hey, Spud. The first time said, spud, you go, what? You'd be really proud, wouldn't. Yeah.

But, um. But I think that it kind of, actually, in a way, probably revealed that I just was probably not in people's thoughts enough to get. To. Get. For the ninny to catch on, you know, because you sort of need to be a real player in.
I think you should have gone somewhat more memorable. I mean, freak or anything. No, no.
Just good advice. Fatty, fatty. Fatty. Popularly.
That's the problem. I wasn't fat at school. And I suppose Kyle didn't have a round, bald head at school, did you? No.
Did you have a nickname?

Not. Not really. I mean, there was a lot of people on the estate that I grew up on, you know, nicknames are big things on estates and that. Like my dad's mates, right. What. What their nicknames did was tell you about them. Do you know how I said about the elephant man's a good name?
Yeah.
Because, like, you know what you're gonna get. If someone said, elephant man's popping around in a bit, it wouldn't be a shock when he walked in.
Yeah.
So it worked in that sort of. Sort of thing, you know. So there was, uh. There was John the screw, right?
John the screw.
Yeah.
Whether he had sex a lot or he worked in a prison.
No, he had a diy shop. So you had him.
Right.
There was, uh, there was Fred the veg.
Yeah. I assume it's because he was at same iq as you or he was in a coma. Yeah.
Right.
There was. It was, it was my uncle Tattoo Stan.
All right.
Yeah. He had, he had like loads of tattoos that he'd just done himself.
Oh, God.

The problem was, because he did his tattoos himself, the ones on his left arm were really good because he was right handed on his right arm. Rubbish. So, so there was him. Great. And there was Jimmy the.
Jimmy the hat?
Yeah.
Did he always wear a hat?
No, he didn't. That, that's, that was the point there, that he never wore a hat.

That's amazing. How can you pick up on someone never wearing a hat? How would you ever notice? I'll tell you what I've noticed about Jimmy. What? He doesn't wear a hat. Why was he not called Jimmy the parrot? Because he never carries a parrot.
That's just the way. I mean, that's how they work in it.
Here comes Jimmy three legs. Why'd you call him that? He hasn't got three legs.
I didn't really have one. Apart from, like, I had a CB. You know, like when you'd go on a CB radio and have a chat to people.

This was a craze in the, was it? Late seventies, early eighties, early eighties. And it was just short band radio, wasn't it? Everyone had these little handsets and they'd speak to each other in the sort of local area.
Yeah, it was mainly, I think it started off with like lorry drivers and it.
Yeah, truckers. Yeah. Because there was that, that thing from like about 1970 convoy.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. So, so I had one of them and meandle. I had two handlebars.
Your nickname.

Yeah. There's loads of code. Code stuff. Yeah, I had a couple. I had. There was pilkyo one because, like I said, there's a lot of Pilkington's and that in Manchester. So I just thought, give it a number if someone's pilky. Oh, two, it's open, you know, I mean, they can have it.
And then there's people scrambling for.
And then. Because I did boxing and that.
Well, you did it once.
Yeah.

I'd box a boy because I thought that that's quite a good image as well. That's kind of like people going, oh, don't mess with him. I mean, if he asks what your handle is, tell him. You know. I mean, it's boxer boy in that. So just add them to. And he used to just go on there and.
Pointless. What is the point of this?
You just. You just meet people, don't you?
You don't meet people. You say, what's your handle, box boy? What's yours? Rubber duck? All right, cheers.
No, then you'll say, like. Then you go, oh, what's your 20?
What's that mean?
Where are you?
Well, why don't you say, where are you?
Because just in case there's someone who's listening in who, you know, you hear about this all the time, don't you? People listening, jotting stuff down.
All right, so just in case someone in the world doesn't know what handle means, that they're out of the loop. They're out of the loop.
It's hardly the, it's not a difficult code to crack, is it? If you're trying to track someone.

Yeah. It's hardly the head of the mafia talking to each other because the FBI are on the wire. It's ridiculous. Like, I go, oh, he keeps saying, what's your handle and they come back with something else. I can't work out what's going on.
No, it's like anything, innit? That's what codes, that's what, that's what codes are all about. And set them up in that.
Go on and tell me. Tell me the code then.
Reveal at long last to the world, what these codes are.
Right, so what's your 20: where are you?
This is better than the enigma.
Right now, here we go.
Right?
How many candles are you burning?
Does that mean how big is your car or something like that? Horsepower or something. Oh, what time is it?
No, how old are you.
What, how old are you, okay.
Right?
How many candles you burning, of course.
Yeah.
So what's the answer come back?
You go-
Brilliant. That code, that code, there's no one gonna work that out. There is no one gonna work that one out.
So let's just play through this conversation. This is, give us an example of how it worked.
Right, so. So you turn it on and that. And you start off. And there was something that you said at the start, like-
Hello!
Breaker breaker?
Yeah, breaker breaker. Do you copy? Or whatever. And then someone will go-
What does copy mean? What his name was?
I want to hear this 'cause I want to hear the fascinating conversations that Karl must have had.
And you go, all right, it's Boxer Boy here.
What's your 20?
